data.title: What to do in Saint Malo? Discover 12 MUST SEE places!
data.meta_description: What to do in Saint Malo? Discover its ramparts, beaches and pleasant surroundings! And lots more to visit in the region!
data.text:
I went to Brittany totally on a whim. The initial idea was to go to Mont Saint Michel (yes, I know, it‚Äôs not really in Brittany) and take advantage of the current low tourist numbers, but as long as I was there, I might as well explore the surrounding area. And that‚Äôs how I ended up in the pretty town of Saint-Malo, the corsair and spa capital (the two are probably unrelated). I‚Äôd already visited it a few years ago, a bit on the fly, with a feeling of unfinished business. So this was my chance to discover a little more, and as we‚Äôll see, there really is a lot to see and do, both in Saint-Malo and in the surrounding area!

Surprisingly, the city of Saint-Malo was founded by‚Ä¶ Saint Malo (known as Saint Mac‚Äôh Low or Saint Maclou, of course) after emigrating to Armorica from Wales in 538. Saint Malo is one of what are known as the Seven Founding Saints of Brittany, and followed Saint Aaron who had settled on a rock just opposite the city of Aleth, founded by the Romans but burnt and pillaged by just about every people who passed through the area (Saxons, Alans, Normans‚Ä¶). In the 12th century, the town was finally moved to the rock of Saint-Malo (where Aaron was, if you can keep up), as it was much more difficult to access (approved by the English). The town was then divided between Brittany and France. With the discovery of the Americas and trade with India, the town took off and became a major port. Jacques Cartier was a Malouin, and privateers such as Surcouf made the town famous. At the end of the Second World War, the town was almost completely razed to the ground (80%) by American bombing raids. However, it was rebuilt identically, thanks in particular to donations from Quebec, testifying to the links between the town and the region ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù by Jacques Cartier. Did you know that the Falkland Islands / Islas Malvinas / Iles Malouines were named after the many sailors from Saint-Malo who called there before crossing the perilous Cape Horn?

Below are the statues of two local children: Jacques Cartier and Surcouf

Saint Malo intra muros, the old town

Of course, the old town is surrounded by those famous ramparts and is the nicest part of town. As mentioned above, it was almost entirely razed to the ground at the end of the Second World War, but fortunately rebuilt almost identically to the original plans. As a result, the city has an ‚Äúold young‚Äù feeling ‚Äì old architecture, old style, but in a (relatively) new way. And it looks great! It‚Äôs a real pleasure to wander through the streets of the city, and especially to try and get away from the 2-3 touristy streets and into the charming little lanes.

Tour des remparts

Saint Malo‚Äôs ramparts are really what make the city so charming and attractive. Surrounding the city walls for 1.7km, you can walk around them in half an hour, or even longer with all the photo breaks. Because the viewpoints are really great. You‚Äôll see the beaches, of course, and the forts, too, but also some lovely views of the city‚Äôs interior. If you have the time, it‚Äôs also the best place to watch the tides, especially from the few little caf√©s overlooking the sea. It‚Äôs ideal, relaxing and refreshing with the wind!

These ramparts, in addition to being very nice, well preserved and with a very nice view, offer great opportunities to see and photograph the sunset. For a start, they‚Äôre very well oriented. You‚Äôve got unobstructed views to the north, east and west, and all in a very nice setting, so there‚Äôs more to it than just being in front of the sun. From the various towers and along the ramparts, you‚Äôll be able to see the lighthouse, Dinard, the islands of Petit and Grand B√©, and Fort National in particular. So, the best way to spend the rest of the day is to stand on the ramparts and find a spot you like. Given the length of the ramparts, you can be sure of finding the right spot for you. And on top of that, with the different tides, it can really add up to something really nice. Ideally, though, the sun should be out, but there‚Äôs not much we can do about that:D

Bidouane Tower

The Bidouane Tower is the largest tower in the ramparts, the one that is furthest forward and really faces the sea. It‚Äôs also one of the city‚Äôs best vantage points. And it‚Äôs a place with a pretty funny history. As we‚Äôve seen, one of the corsair town‚Äôs main missions was to nail the English and catch all the ships passing through the area. Louis XIV, sensing the tide was turning, decided it stank a bit, and asked Vauban to fortify the town even further in preparation for battle, as well as adding artillery and gunpowder in anticipation. A great idea: place explosives in the most accessible tower, which is bound to give ideas to the Anglo-Dutch coalition (and, more broadly, the Augbourg League), and the English spend 2 years building a war machine whose objective is to crash into the Bidouane Tower and detonate what was stored there. Obviously, not everything goes according to plan. After a superbly botched raid on the city, the British send this infernal machine towards the Bidouane Tower, but a gust of wind blows it onto the rocks. As the boat sank, the captain tried to light the gunpowder. There‚Äôs a street in town called Rue du Chat qui Danse, named after the only victim of the raid, a cat that received an ember on its tail. Teasing, those Malouins üòÄ

Totally on the other side, at the level of the Saint-Thomas entrance to the north, we‚Äôll find, in my opinion, the most beautiful part of Saint Malo. This is the castle of Duchess Anne, future Queen of France (among other things, she‚Äôs got quite a pedigree!), defeated by the Dukes of Brittany to establish their domination over the city of Saint Malo. Since then, the castle has become the H√¥tel de Ville and the museum (soon to be transferred), and it‚Äôs not necessarily possible to visit it. A pity, as the exterior is magnificent.

The islands of Grand B√© and Petit B√©

Just opposite the ramparts, these two islands are only accessible at low tide. So make sure you check the tide before you go, otherwise you‚Äôll have to wait 6 hours üòÄ On the Ile du Grand B√©, you‚Äôll have a magnificent view of the ramparts of Saint Malo and, if the weather‚Äôs fine, beautiful turquoise water. It‚Äôs a big rock and requires a bit of effort to get to the top, but it‚Äôs well worth it! You‚Äôll also find Chateaubriand‚Äôs tomb, anonymous and facing the sea, but once there, you might as well take the opportunity to visit the island of Petit B√©, a rikiki island with a Vauban fort, in the series of those used to prevent the English and Dutch from taking the town. You can visit it, and it‚Äôs pretty quick, so there‚Äôs little risk of getting stuck here. Access is super-easy, from the Sillon beach, at the Bidouane tower, which is hard to miss.

I shouldn‚Äôt surprise many, but the town of Saint Malo is surrounded by beaches. And with the very high tides, we‚Äôre going to have huge, beautiful beaches for part of the day. The tides come and go very quickly, so you can play with the reflections between the sand and the water when the weather‚Äôs fine. I confess I‚Äôm not much of an original when it comes to these beaches, but the ones around Fort National are great. Then there‚Äôs the tiny Plage du Mole, at the foot of the ramparts and enclosed, with few people on it but plenty around, sheltered from the wind.

Okay, it‚Äôs super clich√©. But Saint Malo is one of the best places for a thalasso, and I know what I‚Äôm talking about. A few years ago, at a rather tense moment, I spent two days at the Thermes de Saint Malo. And it felt great! It‚Äôs not cheap (but you can regularly find special offers), but boy, the massages, baths, jets and all, with the seafront, it feels really good. I‚Äôve only been to one institute, so I can‚Äôt tell you what‚Äôs best and what‚Äôs best to avoid. All I know is that I really enjoyed being at the Thermes de St Malo. Well, I didn‚Äôt have to look far, it‚Äôs the most famous üòÄ (the view over the beach is pretty good, and the baths are crazy). There are quite a few others, so I can only advise you to compare services and prices

One of France‚Äôs largest aquariums is located in Saint Malo, and it‚Äôs a pretty good one. You‚Äôll find the region‚Äôs ecosystem, as well as a tropical basin, an abyssal basin (with strange creatures in it!) and a mangrove swamp. There are two main attractions in this aquarium, the famous Nautibus, a 4-person mini submarine that moves around the tanks, and the Abyssal room, a deep-sea diving simulator. I think it‚Äôs great fun, and I loved it when I was a kid (I still do, I admit).

You can find out more about the aquarium on their official website, which costs ‚Ç¨12 for children and ‚Ç¨17 for adults

Discover the bay of Saint Malo by boat

Did you know? There‚Äôs another way to discover Saint Malo, its bay and the surrounding area. You can hire a boat for one or more days and travel from Saint Malo to Dinard via Dinan on the magnificent Rance. From what I‚Äôve seen, you can hire a boat whether you‚Äôve got a license or not, as some boats are ‚Äúsupplied‚Äù with a skipper. I particularly recommend Filovent, a specialist in boat hire, which has plenty of availability in Saint Malo and a wide range of rental facilities. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a Zodiac for a day or a boat with cabin and bathroom for several days of relaxation, you should be able to find what you‚Äôre looking for!

But if you don‚Äôt have a boating license and would like a local sailor to show you around the bay, then you have the option of using the Marin Malouin company, a very nice boat trip for 1h30.

Almost indispensable! The Mont Saint Michel is a marvel less than an hour‚Äôs drive from Saint-Malo. I‚Äôll do a super-full article on it, but I‚Äôd advise coming during high tides and ideally doing sunrise or sunset. The colors are magnificent. And although the Mont is fairly quick to visit, take the time to visit the abbey, but above all to walk around it, in the bay, to take in the different viewpoints, it‚Äôs super pleasant. A practical tip: the Mont is accessible 24/24, so you can come very early to visit the narrow streets and be the first at the Abbey (for which it‚Äôs best to book your ticket in advance, as on this site), knowing that it‚Äôs possible to come to Mont Saint Michel by train!

About ten kilometers east of Saint Malo, you‚Äôll find the pretty town of Cancale. Of course, the main attraction is the famous oysters, but that‚Äôs not all. You can also watch the spectacle of the oysters being picked up before the tide comes back in, take a stroll around the town, which is well worth a visit, and also go to the superb Pointe du Grouin to the north of the town, a perfect place to stroll, feel like you‚Äôre in the middle of nature and enjoy the sunset.Cancale is one of the most beautiful places on the Emerald Coast!

When you arrive in Dinard, you‚Äôre in another world. A casino, magnificent and truly impressive houses, it‚Äôs a town that contrasts greatly with Dinan or Saint Malo. It‚Äôs a nice town, but what I really enjoyed was the seafront, walking along the rocks for a few kilometers to get a breath of fresh air in a magnificent setting. And as it‚Äôs right opposite Saint Malo, you‚Äôve got a great view of the city and, if the weather‚Äôs right, it‚Äôll make for some great sunrises and sunsets. From the beach, take the time to walk along the coast (before the tide gets too high!) towards the east, it‚Äôs really beautiful and refreshing! During the summer months, there‚Äôs an evening light show, but‚Ä¶ the night I was there it was cancelled. Damn.

A beautiful medieval town on the banks of the Rance. But Dinan isn‚Äôt just a pretty little port, it‚Äôs also an old town behind ramparts, a preserved historic center and a castle still standing. Dinan‚Äôs magnificent stone streets and half-timbered houses make it a real pleasure to stroll through the town, to get lost and, above all, to take your time. What‚Äôs more, there are some really good cr√™peries. I‚Äôm going to write you a little article with all the info you need on Dinan, but above all, take the Rue du Petit Fort into the heart of the town, ideally early in the morning or at the end of the day to keep the crowds down, and don‚Äôt hesitate to take the few mini alleys on the sides, it‚Äôs really quite cute.

We‚Äôre only 45 minutes from Saint-Malo but it‚Äôs well worth the trip! Fort la Latte is a very nice 14th-century Vauban-style fortified castle built on a rocky cape that‚Äôs really not easy to access. Very well preserved and very well maintained, it‚Äôs not only a great place to visit, but also offers superb views of the Brittany coast. Another advantage of this castle is that it‚Äôs located on the GR34, a magnificent hiking trail that circumnavigates Brittany. And from here, you can go to Cap Frehel, which isn‚Äôt far (1h30 at first sight), along a truly magnificent coastline, turquoise waters and pretty cliffs. Cap Frehel, that is! It‚Äôs also a beautiful spot, especially for sunsets. It‚Äôs made of pink sandstone, so the colors are very pretty, and the cliffs are 70m high. Really, it‚Äôs a great place to come in the late afternoon for the slightly softer colors, a good gust of wind, and a magnificent view of the coast and cliffs. There‚Äôs a parking lot at the lighthouse, but I‚Äôd recommend either coming from Fort la Latte or, simpler and closer and just as beautiful, from the parking lot halfway up the coast. It‚Äôs a very easy 30/45min walk and a fantastic view of nature, the coast, the sea and the superb colors.

I thought this was a tourist trap, but it‚Äôs not! Recommended by the restaurateur at the Petit Galet cr√™perie (very good) in Fort la Latte, the Mus√©e du Cidre is, as its name suggests, a museum that retraces the history of cider making, fun and interesting with several videos and old machines. But, most importantly for our taste buds, it‚Äôs run by a family of producers, and so there‚Äôs tasting of super good ciders and apple juice. I might as well tell you that I‚Äôve put the heat on the CB, and the prices are very reasonable. It‚Äôs located a little south of Saint Malo, in Pleudihen sur Rance

The city itself is pretty easy to get around. But the great thing about Saint Malo is the beaches, the activities, the whole environment, the pretty houses. You don‚Äôt have to go to a thalasso to enjoy the benefits of the city, so it‚Äôs perfectly possible to stay in Saint Malo, take 2-3 days to do the city, relax and then take advantage of the surrounding area, like Dinan, Dinard and others as mentioned above. I had decided to stay closer to Mont Saint Michel for a week, but clearly you can spend that week in Saint Malo, it‚Äôs even more convenient and you drive less.

A week to visit the surrounding area, the Emerald Coast and the C√¥tes d‚ÄôArmor, is not bad I think.

But if you want to discover more from Brittany, why not heading south in Morbihand and discover the Carnac menhir alignments

There‚Äôs a huge range of hotels in Saint Malo, so we‚Äôll try to get a clearer picture. First of all, it‚Äôs worth noting that prices between low and high season vary by as much as double. The prices I‚Äôm going to give you are for the high season and double rooms, so as not to have any surprises. Within the city walls, it‚Äôs obviously a little more expensive, but also super-expensive, I must admit. You‚Äôll find quite a few, the best being the 4* Golden Tulip du Grand B√© at 130‚Ç¨. The Quic en Groigne and the H√¥tel des Abers, at ‚Ç¨100, are among the best-rated hotels within easy reach of the city center. At less than ‚Ç¨100, there are also a number of very decent hotels, such as the Ajoncs d‚Äôor at ‚Ç¨80 and the H√¥tel de France and Chateaubriand. Outside the city center, especially along the beaches, there are some superb spa/thermal hotels, such as the Oceania at ‚Ç¨170 and the famous H√¥tel des Thermes at over ‚Ç¨200. For more classic seaside hotels, there are fine 4* hotels at around 110/130, such as the Mercure St Malo or the superb Villefromoy mansion. If you want to sleep in a ch√¢teau, then the magnificent Ch√¢teau du Colombier is for you, starting at 130‚Ç¨. Finally, a little further out, in classic but very good and functional hotels, we have the Kyriad Prestige at 85‚Ç¨ or the Ibis on the Sillon beach at 83‚Ç¨. And there‚Äôs a lot more! I‚Äôve just made a selection of what stood out, was the most relevant, and removed the crazy stuff. But you‚Äôre bound to find what you‚Äôre looking for üôÇ

From Paris, it‚Äôs super simple. There are direct trains (between 2h15 and 2h45) from Montparnasse, otherwise there‚Äôs a stop in Rennes and you have to take a TER. It takes barely 3 hours in total, which is still reasonable. From other cities, it‚Äôs at best one change, if not two. At least one change in Paris (even from Bordeaux), then Rennes. Otherwise, there are a few possibilities by bus, but it‚Äôs really not the most convenient. You can take a look here at Flixbus. It exists, it‚Äôs done, but it‚Äôs a bit long (and not particularly expensive)
